Fales Library and Special Collections
Sylvester Manor Archive
Sylvester, Nathaniel, 1610-1680
L'Hommedieu, Ezra, 1734-1811
Fiske, Andrew, 1912-1992
Horsford, Eben Norton, 1818-1893
Gardiner, Samuel Smith, 1789-1859
MSS.208
88.37 Linear Feet (159 boxes)
1649-1996 Sylvester Manor is the home of the original European settlers on Shelter Island in eastern Long Island, New York, created in 1652 with the arrival of Nathaniel and Grissell Sylvester. For over 350 years and continuing to this day, the Manor has remained with descendents of the original Sylvesters, and the Sylvester Manor Archive contains documents dating from its mid-17th century European settlement to the late-20th century. The earliest documents provide evidence of an operational northern provisioning plantation involved in the Atlantic trade of the 17th century, while later portions of the collection document the lives of several notable descendents including: Ezra L’Hommedieu, an attorney and politician from the American Revolutionary Era, Samuel Smith Gardiner, an attorney from a prominent family of eastern Long Island, and Eben Norton Horsford, successful entrepreneur and scientist at the forefront of the development of American food science and chemistry.
Conditions Governing Use
Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.
Conditions Governing Access
Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.
Related Archival Material
Dering Papers, Shelter Island Historical Society, Shelter Island, New York.
Horsford Family Papers, Institute Archives and Special Collections, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, New York.
Rumford Chemical Company Records MSS 13 SG 2, Rhode Island Historical Society, Providence, Rhode Island.
Arrangement
Materials are divided into record groups by their general family affiliation (Sylvester, L’Hommedieu, Gardiner, Horsford, and Fiske) and subdivided into series consisting of individuals’ papers. Women that crossed family divisions, such as Mary Catherine L’Hommedieu (Gardiner), and Phoebe Gardiner (Horsford), were included in their married family because most records date from after marriage. Sub-series are identified by the document or material types. Materials are arranged depending on the record type; correspondence is arranged alphabetically by correspondent and then chronologically, most other materials are arranged chronologically except where noted.
Materials are divided into record groups by their family affiliation (Sylvester, L’Hommedieu, Gardiner, Horsford, and Fiske). These record groups are then subdivided into series consisting of individuals’ papers. Women that crossed family divisions, such as Mary Catherine L’Hommedieu Gardiner, and Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford, were included in their married family because most records date from after marriage. Subseries are grouped by the document or material types. Most materials are arranged chronologically except where noted; correspondence is arranged alphabetically by correspondent and then chronologically where applicable.

Scope and Contents
The Sylvester Manor Archive includes correspondence, financial records, manuscripts, photographs, artworks, and realia from the owners and related family members of the Sylvester Manor. These materials document over 350 years of American history. The earliest items are legal and financial documentation such as land deeds pertaining to the purchase of property on Long Island, and includes the signature of noted Mantaukett tribe sachem Wyandanch. The earliest items also document Atlantic trade of the late 17th and early 18th century through wills and ledgers. Later records are the largely the personal records of the individuals who lived at Sylvester Manor, several of whom had noteworthy careers in their respective fields. The records of three individuals comprise the bulk of the collection: Ezra L’Hommedieu, a prominent attorney and politician; Samuel Smith Gardiner, a Long Island and New York attorney; and Eben Norton Horsford, an early leader in food chemistry and owner of the Rumford Chemical Works. Other significant groups of records include the early records of the Sylvester, Brinley, and Lloyd families, as well as the papers of Cornelia Horsford. A significant number of photographs dating from approximately the 1870's through the 1930's document Sylvester Manor and its grounds as well as members of the Horsford and Fiske families.
Historical Note
Sylvester Manor and its grounds are located on Shelter Island, an 8,000-acre island situated between the north and south forks of eastern Long Island that was inhabited by Manhansett Native Americans until its purchase in 1651 by the first permanent European settlers. Nathaniel Sylvester, an Englishman born and raised in Amsterdam, and three Barbadian planters, his brother, Constant, Thomas Middleton, and Thomas Rouse, bought the property to use in the Caribbean provisioning trade. Enslaved Africans, impressed Natives, and European indentured servants raised livestock, produced timber for barrels, and grew food to sell in the West Indies, where most arable land was devoted to valuable sugar cane. In 1653, Nathaniel (Nathaniell in most records) Sylvester and his wife Grissell Brinley (also recorded Grizzell), married and moved to Shelter Island, creating the establishment that would later bear their family name. The property was granted royal manor status by Governor Richard Nicoll of New York Colony in 1666.
In 1752 with the death of Brinley Sylvester, the estate passed to his daughter, Mary (Nathaniel’s great-great granddaughter), and her husband Thomas Dering. The Manor remained in the Dering family for another two generations before debt forced the sale of the property. Dering records do not appear in any number in the Archive. The property was purchased from the Derings in 1827 by Samuel Smith Gardiner, a Suffolk County and New York attorney who had married into a different branch of Sylvester descendents.
Samuel Gardiner’s wife was Mary Catherine L’Hommedieu, the daughter of Ezra L’Hommedieu, a very prominent attorney, national and state political representative, Suffolk County Clerk for some twenty years, and a great-great grandson of Nathaniel Sylvester. Although Ezra L’Hommedieu never owned Sylvester Manor, the collection houses a substantial volume of his papers. The Gardiners produced three daughters, Mary L’Hommedieu Gardiner, Phoebe Dayton Gardiner (sometimes spelled Phebe, particularly in earlier records), and Frances (Fanny) Gardiner.
Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner wed Eben Norton Horsford, a professor of chemistry at Harvard University, a pioneer in food science, and founder of the Rumford Chemical Works in Providence, Rhode Island. Mary and E.N. produced four daughters, Lillian (also Lilian), Mary Katherine (Kate), Gertrude, and Mary Gardiner (Mamie). Mary died in 1855, and E.N. Horsford married her sister Phoebe two years later. Phoebe gave birth to one daughter, Cornelia Conway Fenton (referred to as Nellie in her younger years). Samuel Gardiner died in 1859, passing the Manor to Phoebe and E.N. Horsford, at which time it became a summer home, as the Horsfords were well established in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Following her mother's death in 1903, Cornelia Horsford, who never married, retained the property until her death in 1944. The property then passed to the Fiske family, a family of Boston attorneys into which Gertrude Horsford had married. Augustus Henry Fiske briefly inherited the Manor before passing the estate to his son Andrew, who held the Manor from 1949 until his death in 1992. His widow, Alice Hench Fiske, retained life interest until her death in 2006.
The original house was probably constructed soon after Nathaniel and Grissell’s arrival. Provisioning activities likely ended in 1680 at Nathaniel’s death, but farming and trading continued. After Brinley Sylvester, a successful merchant operating regionally in the New England and New York sphere, tore down the first dwelling, he constructed the current surviving house around 1735. By the time Samuel Gardiner became the owner of the manor in the early 19th century, the Manor property had been significantly reduced and much of the remaining arable land was leased to local farmers. When the Horsfords took possession of the manor, they hosted members of Boston's intellectual and social elite during the summers. While some small-scale farming continued, the existing gardens were formalized and expanded. The Horsfords set up monuments and fenced enclosures, including two extant graveyards, to relate their understanding of the landscape features of the property's history. After her mother's death, Cornelia Horsford maintained the home as a summer residence; continuing work on the gardens and overseeing a substantial renovation to the residence by the well-known architect, Henry Bacon, in 1908.
The estate currently comprises approximately 243 acres including the manor house, several subsidiary houses, as well as barns and out-buildings, most of which date to the nineteenth century. Sylvester Manor remains in the possession of family descendents and is today being cultivated as an educational organic farm. In addition, nine seasons of field schools were conducted by archaeological teams from the University of Massachusetts Boston, providing further information on the original buildings and activities conducted on the site. See http://www.fiskecenter.umb.edu/excavations.htm for information on the archaeological activities.
Due to the large number of individuals whose records are included in the Archive, more detailed Biographical Notes are made at the appropriate level of the finding aid.

Provenance
The Sylvester Manor Archive consists of materials retrieved from the Sylvester Manor House on Shelter Island. These materials were donated to NYU by Eben Fiske Ostby. Alice Hench Fiske intitiated the donation, and in 2008, Mac Griswold oversaw the process with the assistance of Melanie Martin.
Preferred Citation
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Sylvester Manor Archive; MSS 208; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.
Separated Materials
Selected printed materials have been removed to Fales Special collections and cataloged. These items are noted in the finding aid. To see a list of cataloged items, search for "Sylvester Manor Archive" in BobCat.
Processing Information Note
Between 2008-2010, the Sylvester Manor Archive was arranged into record groups by family affiliation, then subdivided into series consisting of individuals' papers, and then chronologically. The finding aid published in 2010 consisted of record titles that described both creator and genre. Sponsored by the R.D.L. Gardiner Foundation, descriptive enhancements were added to the finding aid from 2014-2015. Scope and content notes in the correspondence series of Record Groups I, III, IV, and V now include physical details and subject information about the personal and professional lives of the Sylvester, Brinley, Lloyd, Gardiner, Horsford, and Fiske families. Record Group I also includes descriptive enhancements to its financial and legal records. During the course of these revisions, creator and genre information were separated into different descriptive fields; some items of similar genre or subject were consolidated; and some items received preservation treatment. For these reasons, the current finding aid reflects changes in box and folder locations.
The Sylvester Manor Archive finding aid published in 2010 without these descriptive enhancements is available here.

Record Group I: Sylvester, Brinley, and Lloyd Families
Scope and Contents
Record Group I includes Sylvester, Brinley and Lloyd family items dating from 1649 to 1786. These documents provide evidence of an early northern provisioning plantation actively involved in the Atlantic trades and employing African slave labor, Native Americans, and early European settlers. Financial and accounting evidence of trading activities as well as a number of wills and land ownership documents of various family members provide detailed inventories of possessions during this period.Series A: Sylvester Family
Biographical Note
The Sylvester Family was involved in the original purchase of Shelter Island in 1651 for the purposes of establishing a provisioning plantation for its Barbados sugar operations. Nathaniel Sylvester (1610 - 1680) was a member of an English merchant family that had briefly relocated to the Netherlands before moving to Barbados to manage the family’s interests in a sugar plantation. He married Grissell (Grizzell) Brinley (1635 - 1687), who was the daughter of Francis Brinley, a merchant of some wealth based in Boston and Rhode Island. The couple came to live on Shelter Island in 1652 as the first Europeans to permanently settle there. The couple produced eleven children, including Giles (Gyles) Sylvester (1657 - 1704), who inherited the heart of the estate from his father, while portions were given to the four other sons (portions of the island had also been given to Constant Sylvester). The Sylvesters were sympathetic to the Quaker religion, and provided shelter to several of its followers during persecutions in other areas of New England. After Nathaniel’s death, the property was no longer affiliated with the sugar plantation in Barbados that had been operated by Nathaniel’s brother Constant. Giles (Gyles) Sylvester died without heir and following a legal dispute, the property passed to Brinley Sylvester (1694 - 1752), Giles’ nephew via his brother Nathaniel II. Brinley Sylvester pursued trading and other maritime merchant activities. He married Mary Burrough and had two daughters, of which Mary Sylvester would marry Thomas Dering and later inherit the estate.
Scope and Contents
Record Group I, Series A: Sylvester Family consists of financial records, legal records, and personal and professional correspondence. Genres range from deeds of property sales, enfranchisements, grants, indentures, inventories, and wills, to bills, bonds and receipts, to letters, notation, and genealogical research. This series also includes the earliest evidence of African American slavery on Shelter Island in the form of Grissell (Grizzell) Sylvester’s last will and testament, dated 1685. These papers lightly refer to Shelter Island manorial business but also include accounts and ledgers of merchant activities in Boston while the settlement identified as part of the Massachusetts Bay Colony.
This series is dominated by sales and settlement papers concerning Horse Neck, a property on the northern shore of Long Island. Horse Neck was purchased by Nathaniel Sylvester for his daughter Grissell (Grizzell) (1654-1691), who was engaged to be married to Latimer Sampson, who died before they were wed. Grissell then married Boston merchant James Lloyd, who appears in this series as well as in Series C: Lloyd Family. Following a dispute over the ownership of the Horse Neck property purchased by Nathaniel Sylvester and given to Latimer Sampson, it was determined that Sampson’s will entitled the property to Grissell and therefore, Lloyd.
The name “Horse Neck” was originally used by Huntington farmers who grazed horses there in the 17th century. Matinecock Native Americans sold Horse Neck (or Caumsett, “place by sharp rock”) to English settlers from Oyster Bay in 1654 before Boston merchant James Lloyd acquired the property in 1676. On March 8, 1685, Lieutenant Governor Thomas Dongan granted James Lloyd the royal patent for Horse Neck, formally renaming it the “Manor of Queens Village,” annexed to Oyster Bay, Queens County. James Lloyd remained in Boston, renting the property out to tenant farmers, but in 1711 his 24-year-old son, Henry, gave up a shipping business in Newport, Rhode Island, to farm the Manor. His “salt box” home, the Henry Lloyd Manor House, stills survives on the grounds of Caumsett State Historic Park, where it has been restored, maintained, and interpreted by the Lloyd Harbor Historical Society.
What was once referred to as Horse Neck is now called Lloyd Neck, and is part of Lloyd Harbor, a village in Suffolk County, while the Incorporated Village of Lloyd Harbor is located in the town of Huntington, Long Island, New York. The Papers of the Lloyd Family of the Manor of Queens Village, Lloyd Neck, Long Island, New York in book (1654-1826) and manuscript form (1654-1822) are preserved at the New York Historical Society.
These materials are arranged chronologically. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If an item is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These items are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.

Letter - Lion Gardiner to John Winthrop: 1649 April 16
Scope and Contents
1 Letter with Notation & Seal
Addressed To: John Winthrop
Sent From: Lion Gardiner
In Reference To: Business; Hay, Food, English lamb
2 Pages, Unbound
Handwritten in Ink
Measurements: 6.5” x 8”
Lion Gardiner (1599 – 1663), an early English settler and soldier in the New World, founded the first English settlement in what became the state of New York on Long Island. His legacy includes Gardiners Island, which is held by his descendants. John Winthrop (January 12, 1587 - March 26, 1649) was a wealthy English Puritan lawyer and one of the leading figures in the founding of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, the first major settlement in what is now New England after Plymouth Colony. The Winthrop Family Papers are preserved at the Massachusetts Historical Society. Legal Record with Notation1654 September 20; 1658 May 1414120

Wyandanch (Wyandance) (born circa 1620 in Montauk, Long Island - died 1660) was a sachem of the Montaukett tribe in the mid-17th century on eastern Long Island. He was an influential "alliance chief," a sachem who was responsible for maintaining friendly relations between his tribe and the settlers.Professional Correspondence1654 October 1014764

Captain John Scott of Long Island (1634–1696) was a royal advisor, military leader, spy, cartographer, attorney, land speculator, and early settler and leader of Long Island. He lobbied to make Long Island the 14th English colony in North America with himself as governor and, when not appointed by the crown, was elected President of Long Island by that region's leaders. Sir Edmund Andros (December 6, 1637 – February 24, 1714) was an English colonial administrator in North America. He was the governor of the Dominion of New England during most of its three-year existence. Andros served as governor of the provinces of New York, East and West Jersey, Virginia, and Maryland. Before his service in North America, he served as bailiff of Guernsey. Andros' tenure in New England was authoritarian and turbulent, as his views were decidedly pro-Anglican, a negative quality in a region home to many Puritans. His actions in New England resulted in his overthrow during the 1689 Boston revolt. Records documenting Andros’ professional life are preserved at the New York Historical Society and the National Archives in Surrey, England.Legal Record with Notation1678 October 1114114

Biographical Note
The Brinley Family Papers are preserved at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, Special Collections and University Archives in the W.E.B. Du Bois Library, in which the following biographical and historical content is provided:
Englishmen and colonial Americans, Loyalists and Patriots, colonial Canadians and American citizens, the members of the Brinley family were a diverse group of characters, ranging from auditors to officers, businessmen, lawyers, legislators, book-collectors, historians, aristocratic ladies and housewives, devoted mothers, husbands, and fathers. A few were slave-holders. Yet through decades of tumultuous social and political change, the family maintained certain distinctive traits and traditions, clinging most notably to their strong ties to England and to the status quo at home. The Brinleys were wealthy, business-minded members of the colonial elite, profoundly Protestant, and most were highly educated and steeped in knowledge. Many became prominent public figures and many more served their respective nations in uniform.
The roots of the Brinley family extend back to England, where the common ancestor of the North American branch of the family, Thomas Brinley (1591 - 1661), served as Auditor of the Revenue for James I and Charles I. Thomas' daughter Grissell (Grizzell) was married to Nathaniel Sylvester. When Thomas' eldest son Francis (1626 - 1719) emigrated to Newport, Rhode Island in the mid-seventeenth century, the family's wealth and prestige were transplanted with him. This series documents Francis' professional life as a merchant.
Scope and Contents
Record Group I, Series B: Brinley Family consists of financial records, legal records, and personal and professional correspondence. Genres range from affidavits, deeds of property sales, indentures, inventories, memorandums, and wills, to bills, receipts, and statements of account, to letters, notation, and genealogical research. While this series lightly refers to family conversations about estate settlements, financial transition, and marriage, it is dominated by property management dealings in Rhode Island and records documenting trade in Boston, MA from Francis Brinley, the eldest son of Thomas Brinley, brother of Nathaniel Sylvester’s wife Grissell (Grizzell). This series' provenance is unique within the Sylvester Manor Archive as it is largely a research series, full of records purchased by Andrew Fiske and added for relevance. These records are marked with [Fiske Purchase] to indicate this difference. See Record Group V: Fiske Family, Series A: Correspondence and Research for documentation of Fiske's genealogical work behind these purchases.
These materials are arranged chronologically. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If an item is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.Commercial correspondence.Personal papers.Boston, MassachusettsFinancial recordsCorrespondenceLegal documents.Legal correspondence.WillsNotes.Letters (correspondence)Deeds.Memorandums.Newport, Rhode IslandPersonal correspondence.Receipts.Legal Record with Notation1672 April 121542

Biographical Note
Horse Neck was purchased by Nathaniel Sylvester for his daughter Grissell (Grizzell) (1654-1691), who was engaged to be married to Latimer Sampson, who died before they were wed. Grissell then married Boston merchant James Lloyd (d. 1698), who appears in this series as well as Series A: Sylvester Family. Following a dispute over the ownership of the Horse Neck property purchased by Nathaniel Sylvester and given to Latimer Sampson, it was determined that Sampson’s will entitled the property to Grissell and therefore, Lloyd.
The name “Horse Neck” was originally used by Huntington farmers who grazed horses there in the 17th century. Matinecock Native Americans sold Horse Neck (or Caumsett, “place by sharp rock”) to English settlers from Oyster Bay in 1654 before James Lloyd acquired the property in 1676. On March 8, 1685, Lieutenant Governor Thomas Dongan granted James Lloyd the royal patent for Horse Neck, formally renaming it the “Manor of Queens Village,” annexed to Oyster Bay, Queens County. James Lloyd remained in Boston, renting the property out to tenant farmers, but in 1711 his 24-year-old son, Henry, gave up a shipping business in Newport, Rhode Island, to farm the Manor. His “salt box” home, the Henry Lloyd Manor House, stills survives on the grounds of Caumsett State Historic Park, where it has been restored, and is maintained and interpreted by the Lloyd Harbor Historical Society.
Horse Neck is now called Lloyd Neck, and is part of Lloyd Harbor, a village in Suffolk County, while the Incorporated Village of Lloyd Harbor is located in the town of Huntington, Long Island, NY. The Papers of the Lloyd Family of the Manor of Queens Village, Lloyd Neck, Long Island, NY in book form (1654-1826) and manuscript form (1654-1822) are preserved at the New York Historical Society.
Scope and Contents
Record Group I, Series C: Lloyd Family consists of financial records, legal records, and personal and professional correspondence. Genres range from deeds of property sales and memorandums, to bills and bonds, to letters, notation, and research. While this series lightly refers to Horse Neck [Lloyd Neck] and Shelter Island estate settlements, or family conversations about financial transition and marriage, this series is dominated by professional correspondence documenting statements of account and transactions in Boston, MA, Newport, RI and New York, NY.
These materials are arranged chronologically. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If an item is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.New York (N.Y.)Newport, Rhode IslandLloyd Neck, NY (Suffolk County)Legal documents.Southampton, NY (Suffolk County)Huntington, NY (Suffolk County)Shelter Island (N.Y.) John Bowne (1627 – 1695) was an English immigrant residing in the Dutch colony of New Netherland, who is honored today as a pioneer in the American struggle for religious liberty. With his wife Hannah Feake (1637 - 1678), great-niece of Governor John Winthrop of Massachusetts, they relocated to Flushing, Long Island in 1661 to practice Quakerism. John Bowne’s journal and related papers are preserved at the New York Historical Society. Legal Record with Notation1685 November 26; 1874 February 51424

Isaac Norris (July 21, 1671 – June 4, 1735) was a merchant and prominent figure in provincial Pennsylvania, including mayor of Philadelphia in 1724. In 1694 he married Mary, daughter of Thomas Lloyd, president of the council. Their son, Isaac, succeeded his father in business and also became active in politics, serving as speaker of the Assembly. Norris was a slave trader and owner. He and Mary Lloyd freed many of the slaves during their lifetimes or in their wills. Their children, including Elizabeth and Isaac Norris, Jr., freed the rest of them. The Papers of Isaac Norris (1742-1860) are preserved at the Historical Society of Pennsylvania. Measurements: 6.5” x 8”Record Group II: L'Hommedieu Family
Scope and Content note
Record Group II: L'Hommedieu Family contains records belonging to Benjamin L’Hommedieu II, but is made up primarily of the personal and business papers of Ezra L’Hommedieu, a prominent New York attorney and statesman of the Revolutionary Era. They include correspondence, legal and accounting records of both personal and professional nature, U.S. and New York State government records, reports and printed materials, published materials, and papers relating to the settling of lands in Central and Northern New York State. In addition, a collection of papers of Ezra’s wife, Mary Catherine Havens L’Hommedieu are included, as are a significant volume of correspondence from two of the executors of his estate, Thomas Lester and Thomas Dering, all of which relate to the maintenance and settlement of the estate and upstate New York lands.Series A: Benjamin L'Hommedieu II
Biographical Note
Benjamin L’Hommedieu II (1694-1755) was the eldest son of Benjamin L’Hommedieu and Patience Sylvester and a grandson of Nathaniel and Grissell Sylvester. Benjamin L’Hommedieu II was a merchant residing in Southold, Long Island. His wed his first wife Mary Conklin in 1713, who later died in 1730. He then married a second time to Martha Bourn (also spelled Bourne in some records) from Sandwich, Massachusetts in 1731.
Scope and Contents

Biographical Note
Although never owner of Sylvester Manor, Ezra L’Hommedieu (1734 - 1811) was a person of considerable prominence in the history of Long Island and New York State. L'Hommedieu was educated at Yale College and graduated in 1754, after which he began his legal practice in Southold, Long Island. The L'Hommedieu family was forced to relocate to Middletown, CT during the occupation of Long Island by British forces during the American Revolution, and again during the blockade in the War of 1812. L'Hommedieu was married twice, first to Charity Floyd in 1765, and after Charity Floyd’s death in 1785, to Mary Catherine Havens in 1803. Ezra and Mary Catherine had one daughter, Mary Catherine L’Hommedieu. Ezra L’Hommedieu was a Patriot, and began public service in 1775 with his election to the Provincial Congress. L'Hommedieu's list of national, state and local political positions is extensive: delegate to the Provincial Congress 1775-1777; member of the New York State Assembly 1777-1783; member of the Continental Congress from 1779-1783 and 1788; member of the New York State Senate from 1784-1792 and again from 1794-1809; member of the state constitutional convention in 1801; Suffolk County Clerk from 1784 to March 1810 and from March 1811 until his death; and Regent of the University of the State of New York 1787-1811. L’Hommedieu was also granted land patents to extensive holdings in the area of the Twenty Townships, a large tract of land purchased from the Oneida Native Americans in 1788 in what is now Central New York. L'Hommedieu also held lands near Plattsburg, NY and Sandwich, MA, the latter stemming from the Bourn family’s property. These items document the surveying, sale and leasing of these lands.
Scope and Contents
Record Group II, Series B pertains to the professional life of Ezra L'Hommedieu in the form of legal records and professional correspondence. Series B includes letters from a number of notable figures in local, state, and national politics, including: George Clinton, Nicoll and William Floyd, David Gelston, General John Smith, Benjamin Tallmadge, Philip Schuyler van Rensselaer, and one letter from Thomas Jefferson.

Biographical Note
Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu was born to Nicoll Havens and Sarah Fosdick of Shelter Island, NY on September 25, 1765. Mary Catherine wed Ezra L'Hommedieu of Southold, Long Island, NY on June 15, 1803. This was Ezra L'Hommedieu's second marriage and they produced one daughter, Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu, born in 1806. Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu's sister Esther Sarah married Sylvester Dering, the son of Thomas Dering, also of Shelter Island. Ezra L'Hommedieu left his estate, which included Sylvester Manor, to Mary Catherine Havens when he passed away on September 27, 1811, and it was later inherited by their daughter Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner and her husband Samuel Smith Gardiner. Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu passed away in 1843.
Scope and Contents
Record Group II, Series C includes personal correspondence primarily among relatives and close family friends of Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu. In addition, Series C includes Ezra L'Hommedieu estate management records, legal documents, and financial papers.Subseries 1: CorrespondenceBarnes, D.H. to Charles Thomas Deringcuid84418222831"Cousin," [Unidentified]cuid8451820 - 18232832Dering, Annacuid8461808, 18242833Dering, Anna & Francescuid84718232834Dering, Charles Thomascuid8481821-18242835Dering, Charles Thomascuid84918242836Dering, Henry P.cuid85018142837Dering, Henry P.cuid8511816 January 22838

Biographical Note
Sylvester Dering was born in 1758 to Boston politician Thomas Dering (circa 1716 - 1785) and daughter of Brinley Sylvester, Mary Sylvester. During his lifetime, Sylvester Dering owned and managed Sylvester Manor, in addition to earning the rank of General during the American Revolutionary War. Dering was a brigadier in the Rhode Island state militia and saw action at the Battle of Oriskany in central NY. Sylvester Dering was also a member of the State Assembly for Suffolk County from 1803 - 1804, and became the first vice-president of the Suffolk County Agricultural Society in 1818. Sylvester Dering married Esther Sarah Havens, sister to Mary Catherine Havens L'Hommedieu, wife of Ezra L'Hommedieu; he was appointed as one of the executors of Ezra L'Hommedieu's estate and passed away in 1820. The Dering Family Papers (1755 - 1896) are housed at the William L. Clements Library of the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, MI.

Biographical and Historical Note
The Gardiners of Shelter Island were descendents of Lion Gardiner, an early English settler and soldier in the New World. In 1639, Lion Gardiner purchased property from the Montaukett Native Americans after his support of the tribe during the Pequot War. With a grant from Charles I, Gardiner procured what became the first colonial English settlement in present-day New York state. What would become Gardiners Island in East Hampton, Suffolk County, was originally in its own jurisdiction affiliated with neither New York nor New England. In 1648, a royal British charter recognized the island as a wholly contained colony, independent of both New York and Connecticut. It was not until the American Revolution was the property declared under New York and East Hampton authority. Gardiners Island has been privately owned for over three hundred years by Lion Gardiner’s descendants, and is the only real estate still intact as part of an original royal grant from the English Crown. This record group features the life and work of Samuel Smith Gardiner and his wife Mary Catherine L’Hommedieu Gardiner.
Scope and Contents
Record Group III: Gardiner Family preserves the personal and professional life of Samuel Smith Gardiner and his wife Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner. Series A: Samuel Smith Gardiner includes genres that range from accounting records, correspondence, political and religious manuscripts, to professional legal papers that document Gardiner's law practices in Suffolk County and larger New York. Series B: Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner features personal correspondence and juvenilia.Series A: Samuel Smith Gardiner
Biographical Note
Son of Captain Abraham Gardiner (1763 - 1796) and Phebe Dayton, Samuel Smith Gardiner (1789 - 1859) was a member of the prominent and wealthy Gardiner family, who traced their ancestry to early settler Lion Gardiner. Samuel Smith Gardiner was educated at Williams College in Massachusetts, managed the Shelter Island estate, and practiced law in Suffolk County and larger New York. Gardiner was one of the secretaries of the NY State Constitutional Convention of 1821, and a member of the NY State Legislature from 1823-1824. Gardiner wed Mary Catherine L’Hommedieu on August 7, 1823. Debt forced the Dering Family to place the Sylvester Manor estate at auction and Samuel Smith Gardiner purchased the manor house and 578 acres for $10,400. Samuel Smith Gardiner and Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner's three daughters Mary L’Hommedieu Gardiner, Phoebe Dayton Gardiner, and Frances Eliza Gardiner would later inherit Samuel's estate. After Mary Catherine L'Hommedieu Gardiner passed away on January 28, 1838, Samuel Smith Gardiner married Susan F. Mott in the mid-1840s, the daughter of Henry Franklin and the widow of William W. Mott. Samuel Smith Gardiner passed away on March 21, 1859.
Samuel Smith Gardiner business management records in the form of accounts, bills, deeds, estate documents, and statements are included in the Horsford Family Papers (1681-1954) at the Rensselaer Institute Archives and Special Collections in Troy, NY.
Scope and Contents
Record Group III, Series A pertains to Samuel Smith Gardiner's personal and professional life in which it includes correspondence, financial records, legal papers, and printed materials in the form of government and political circulars, newspapers, and religious manuscripts. In addition, Record Group III, Series A includes David Gardiner professional papers.
Selected printed materials have been removed to Fales Special Collections and cataloged. Please search Bobcat to locate these items.Subseries 1: Correspondence
Scope and Contents
Record Group III, Series A, Subseries 1 pertains to Samuel Smith Gardiner’s personal and professional life in the form of correspondence, financial records, and legal records. Genres range from clippings, ephemera, handdrawn maps, indentures, invitations, letters, memorandums, receipts, and statements of account. This subseries is dominated by items that capture Samuel Smith Gardiner’s professional life through letters with clerks, landowners, lawyers, politicians, solicitors, students, and tenants, featuring business conversations about estate management and execution, farm rentals and sales, and property insurance, maintenance, and transactions in Boston, MA, Long Island and larger New York State, and Ontario, Canada. In addition, this series includes a handwritten transcription of an agreement with the Montauk (Montaukett) Native American tribe concerning East Hampton property in 1702 and twenty-three letters from John Tyler, the tenth President of the United States and first lady Julia Gardiner Tyler, Samuel Smith Gardiner’s niece.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].
In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If an item is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. John Tyler (March 29, 1790 – January 18, 1862) was the tenth President of the United States (1841–1845). He was elected vice president on the 1840 Whig ticket with William Henry Harrison, and became president after his running mate's death in April 1841. Harrison's death made Tyler the first vice president to succeed to the presidency without being elected to the office. The personal papers of the Tyler Family can be found at the Special Collections Research Center at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, VA, while the executive papers of John Tyler while he was Governor of Virginia can be found at the Library of Virginia in Richmond, VA. Julia Gardiner Tyler (May 17, 1820 – July 10, 1889) was the second wife of John Tyler, the tenth President of the United States, and served as First Lady of the United States from June 26, 1844 to March 4, 1845. Julia Gardiner Tyler was born in 1820 on Gardiner's Island off the eastern tip of Long Island, New York, one of the largest privately owned islands in the United States. She was the daughter of David Gardiner, a prominent landowner and New York State Senator from 1824 - 1828, and his wife Juliana (née McLachlan). Julia was raised in the New York town of East Hampton as well as in the small hamlet of Bay Shore, Long Island; Bay Shore was called Penataquit until 1868, and even earlier, Awixa. Manuscripts documenting Julia Gardiner Tyler's life are preserved at the Earl Gregg Swem Library at the College of William and Mary, the East Hampton Library, the Library of Congress, the Virginia Historical Society, and the Yale University Library. Joseph Christopher Yates (November 9, 1768 – March 19, 1837) was an American lawyer, politician, statesman, and founding trustee of Union College. Yates’ career in government included serving as the first mayor of his birthplace, Schenectady, NY, in addition to the state’s seventh governor between 1823-1824, a senator, and a Supreme Court justice. Joseph Christopher Yates is included in the Christopher Yates Papers (1677-1936) at Syracuse University Special Collections Research Center in Syracuse, NY. Biographical Note
Mary Catherine L’Hommedieu Gardiner (July 6, 1806 - January 28, 1838) was the only daughter of Ezra and Mary L’Hommedieu. She married Samuel Smith Gardiner in 1823 and gave birth to three daughters: Mary L’Hommedieu Gardiner in 1824, Phoebe Dayton Gardiner in 1826, and Frances Eliza Gardiner (Fanny) in 1832. Mary and Phoebe would both marry Eben Norton Horsford, whose personal and professional life are documented in Record Group IV: Horsford Family. Frances married George Martin Lane, a Harvard professor of Latin Language and Literature, in 1857.
Scope and Contents
Record Group III, Series B pertains to Mary Catherine L’Hommedieu Gardiner’s personal life in the form of correspondence, financial records, and juvenilia. Genres range from letters and gifts, meeting minutes and receipts, original and collected poetry, to penmanship practice materials, and testimonies of religious faith. This subseries is dominated by items that capture Gardiner’s conversations with family members, friends, and school acquaintances in reference to courtship, education, family, faith, marriage, and travel. These exchanges also include those between Mary and Samuel during the events leading up to their marriage. Mary’s childhood penmanship practice materials also speak to the writing traditions of the time period.
These materials are lightly arranged alphabetically by surname of the individual in contact with Gardiner or the conversation subject. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If an item is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.Financial Record with Notation

Scope and Contents
Record Group IV: Horsford Family preserves the personal and professional materials of Eben Norton Horsford and his immediate family. Series A: Eben Norton Horsford includes record types that range from correspondence, ephemera, financial records, legal documentation, journals, printed materials, and research. While they also include manuscripts and printed materials, Series B - I are dominated by the personal correspondence of Horsford’s two wives and five daughters.Series A: Eben Norton Horsford
Biographical Note
American chemist Eben Norton Horsford (July 27, 1818 - January 1, 1893), was the only son of missionary and politician Jerediah Horsford and his wife Maria Charity Horsford of Moscow, NY. In addition to Eben, Jerediah and Maria Charity produced four daughters: Maria Horsford Byam, Julia Horsford Norton, Eliza Horsford Tryon, and Laura Horsford.
Eben earned a civil engineering degree from RPI (Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute) in 1838 and contributed to the Geographical Survey of New York under the supervision of geologist and RPI paleontologist James Hall. Between 1840 - 1844, Eben lectured at Delaware’s Newark College, in addition to teaching mathematics and natural sciences at the Albany Female Academy, where he would meet sisters Mary L’Hommedieu Gardiner and Phoebe Dayton Gardiner as students. Between 1844 - 1847, Eben studied with chemist Justus Freiherr von Liebig in Giessen, Germany and returned to the U.S. to marry Mary L’Hommedieu Gardiner and serve as the Rumford Professor and Lecturer on the Application of Science to the Useful Arts at Harvard University, where he would steadily publish and teach until 1863.
Mary gave birth to four daughters: Mary Leila (Lilian) in 1848, Mary Katherine (Kate) in 1850, Gertrude Hubbard in 1852, and Mary Gardiner (Mamie) in 1855. Mary died a few months after the birth of Mamie. Eben wed Mary’s sister Phoebe in 1857, and the couple produced one daughter, Cornelia Conway Felton, in 1860.
In 1858, Eben founded Rumford Chemical Works with George Francis Wilson, who successfully managed his chemical developments and inventions. Eben’s most successful development was the modern formula for baking powder, but he also produced acid phosphate, anti-chlorine, yeast powder, and developed a process for condensing milk. During the American Civil War, Eben devised an “improved army ration” of dehydrated meat; in addition, Rumford generated methods of attaching armor plating to warships, manufacturing fire-proof safes, and water analyses for municipalities in the Boston area.
In 1873, Eben was selected as a member of the U.S. Scientific Commission for the Vienna Exposition. Eben also strongly supported education and professional options for women while becoming Wellesley College’s Board of Visitors President in 1877 and honorary class member in 1886. It was also during this time that Eben began researching and publishing work about Viking settlements in America, namely the “lost city of Norumbega,” which is believed to be present Weston, MA, in which he had a monument erected in 1889.
The Horsfords led an active social life centered on their Cambridge and Harvard communities. They acquainted with several members of the “Boston Brahmin,” in addition to prominent figures of the Cambridge intelligentsia and literary community, including Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr., Henry Longfellow, Sarah Orne Jewett, and Helen Hunt Jackson to name a few.
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series A pertains to Eben Norton Horsford’s personal and professional life in the form of eleven different subseries arranged by record type ranging from correspondence in the form of invitations, letters, postcards, and telegrams, Cambridge and Shelter Island estate management documentation in the form of architectural sketches, indentures, and memorandums, financial records in the form of account books, bills, and receipts, patent related circulars, ephemera, and other printed materials, personal and professional writing in the form of collected research, diaries, journals, and notebooks.
Selected printed materials have been removed to Fales Special collections and cataloged. Please search Bobcat to locate these items.Subseries 1: Correspondence
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series A, Subseries 1, pertains to Eben Norton Horsford’s personal and professional life in the form of communication with his family, friends, and vast business network. With efforts to separate social and professional content, Subseries 1 is organized by four different subsubseries that feature over 4,243 (10,542 pages) assorted forms of communication that detail distinctive professional projects and or subjects, but there remains a significant amount of overlap. Genres range from announcements, artwork and illustrations, calling / visiting cards, ephemera and printed material in the form of advertisements, clippings, and circulars, collected and original poetry, drafts and reproductions of conversations in the form of handwritten transcriptions and photocopies, financial and legal records, invitations, letters, photographic prints, postcards, research notation, and telegrams.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].
In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.Subsubseries a: Academic and Family
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series A, Subseries 1, subsubseries a: Academic and Family pertains to Eben Norton Horsford’s personal and professional life in the form of communication records with his family, friends, and vast business network. While the isolation of subsubseries a: Academic and Family is an effort to separate specific social and commercial content from the rest of Series A, this subsubseries features a significant amount of overlap. Although this portion of Eben’s correspondence houses personal communication with his immediate and extended family and or concern of private business, such as Cambridge and Shelter Island property management, these materials also illuminate Eben’s childhood, education, and professional ascension in chemistry, food science, and local history.
Academic and Family features over 3,325 letters (8,383 pages) dominated by conversations with local and international academics, professionals across fields of industry, and the general public concerning Eben’s public and scholastic circulation of his work with David Zeisberger’s Indian Dictionary and the history of Viking settlements in America. Genres include announcements, artwork and illustrations, calling / visiting cards, drafts of unsent correspondence, financial and legal records, invitations, letters and reproductions of letters in the form of photocopies and transcriptions, photographic prints, postcards, printed ephemera in the form of advertisements, clippings, notices, and telegrams. Eben conversed with renown American and international activists, archaeologists, administrators, architects, astronomers, bibliographers, botanists, chemists, economists, editors, educators, historians, indexers, librarians, ministers, philosophers, physicists, poets, politicians, social reformers, social scientists, theologians, and writers. In addition, this unique set of correspondence demonstrates the Horsford family’s active social life among their Cambridge and Harvard communities, several members of the “Boston Brahmin,” and prominent figures of the New England literary intelligentsia.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].
In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. Charlotte Fiske Bates (Mme. Rogé) (November 30, 1838 – September 1, 1916) was an American writer. Bates published "Risks and Other Poems" (1879) which includes 120 poems, ten sonnets, ten French translations (which were originally done for Longfellow's Poems of Places), and five epithalamia. Bates also contributed many articles to magazines, and edited the Longfellow Birthday Book (1881), Seven Voices of Sympathy(1881), and the Cambridge Book of Poetry and Song(1882). Much of Bates' work is available through New York University Libraries via BobCat. Baxter, James Phinney: Macworth Island, MEcuid17041889 July 35619

James Curtis Booth (July 28, 1810 – March 21, 1888) was an American chemist who was the melter and refiner at the U.S. Mint in Philadelphia for many years. Booth was born in Philadelphia, was educated at the Hartsville Seminary, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1829, and later studied at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, New York from 1831 to 1832. He visited Germany between 1833 and 1835, spending the year of 1833 in Professor Friedrich Wöhler's private laboratory in Hesse-Cassel, and then spending nine months in the laboratory of Professor Gustav Magnus in Berlin. He opened a chemistry laboratory in Pennsylvania in 1836 for teaching purposes, and when the demand for teaching and chemical analysis increased, he was assisted by Dr. Martin Hans Boyè until 1845. From 1848, Thomas H. Garrett was his associate, and in 1881 the firm became "Booth, Garrett and Blair." The James Curtis Booth Papers (1785-1944) are preserved at the Othmer Library of Chemical History, Chemical Heritage Foundation in Philadelphia, PA. Gail Borden, Jr. (November 9, 1801 – January 11, 1874), was a native New Yorker who settled in Texas in 1829, where he worked as a land surveyor, newspaper publisher, and inventor. Borden is most known as the developer of condensed milk in 1853; demand was high for his product by the Union Army during the American Civil War. The Gail Borden Papers (1830-1956) are preserved at the Daughters of the Republic of Texas Library in San Antonio, TX.Borden, Richard P: Cambridge, MA cuid17311890 May 55646

Sarah Hopkins Bradford (August 20, 1818 – June 25, 1912) was an American historian and writer. James Elliot Cabot (June 18, 1821 – January 16, 1903) was an American author and philosopher. Born in Boston, Cabot attended and taught at Harvard; he was a transcendentalist, edited the Massachusetts Quarterly Review, and wrote a biography of Ralph Waldo Emerson. The Cabot Family Papers (1786-1945) are preserved in the Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library at the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Studies, Harvard University in Cambridge, MA. Dr. Ezra Slocum Carr (March 9, 1819 - November 27, 1894) was originally trained as a medical doctor but taught in several scientific fields including agriculture and natural sciences. Carr taught at the University of California at Berkeley and the University Wisconsin, in which he also served on the Board of Regents. One-time California Superintendent of Public Instruction, Carr was a progressive educator, friend, and mentor to John Muir, the Scottish-American naturalist, author, and early advocate of wilderness preservation in the United States. The Carr Family Collection (1870-1936) is preserved at the Pasadena Museum of History Research Library and Archives in Pasadena, CA. In addition, The Papers of Jeanne C. Smith Carr (1842-1903), Ezra's wife, are preserved at the Huntington Library in San Marino, CA. Cartwright, AS: Shelter Island, NYcuid18111887 January 35740

Joseph Lemuel Chester (April 30, 1821 – May 26, 1882) was an American anti-slavery spokesman, City Council member, educator, genealogist, poet and writer. Mary Bradford Crowninshield (April 1844 - October 14, 1913) was an American children’s fiction writer. Mary was the daughter of American writer Sarah Elizabeth Hopkins Bradford and prominent New York attorney John Melancthon Bradford, Jr. Mary married naval officer Arent Schuyler Crowninshield who saw combat during the American Civil War, advanced to Rear Admiral rank, and worked for the Bureau of Navigation. The Crowninshield Family Papers (1697-1909) are preserved at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, MA. Cullum, George W: Newport, RI & New York, NY

Frank Hamilton Cushing (July 22, 1857 – April 10, 1900) was an American anthropologist and ethnologist. Cushing's pioneering studies of the Native American Zuni tribe of New Mexico by entering into their culture helped establish participant observation as a common anthropological research strategy. The Frank Hamilton Cushing Papers (1876-1892) are preserved at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University, New Haven, CT. Historian Nicholas Darnell Davis (1846 - 1915) was born in Grenada, and spent brief periods in Mauritius and Sierra Leone, but his main public career was in British Guiana [Guyana], where he served as Postmaster General (1876-1881), Comptroller of Customs (1881-1895), and Auditor-General (1895-1908). Davis had a life-long interest in the history of the West Indies and more specifically of Barbados; he contributed many historical articles to newspapers and periodicals in British Guiana, Barbados and the United States. The Nicholas Darnell Davis Collection (1752-1915) is preserved at the Royal Commonwealth Society Library, Cambridge University in England. Davis, WM: Cambridge, MA cuid18801887 January 135855

Charles Avery Doremus (September 6, 1851 – December 2, 1925) was an American chemist. Charles was the son of chemist and physician Robert Ogden Doremus, and studied the College of the City of New York and at the universities of Leipzig and Heidelberg. Charles was a holder of patents for a process for softening water, a gas furnace, producing hydrofluoric acid, extracting alumina from clay, and for the extraction of potash from feldspar. William Nelson's Genealogy of the Doremus Family is available through New York University Libraries via BobCat. Estelle Emma Skidmore Doremus (May 6, 1830 – May 21, 1905) was the daughter of Hubbard Skidmore, who served in the American Revolutionary War, and became a charter member and honorary vice president general of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution (DAR). Estelle was also a charter officer and regent of the New York City chapter of the DAR (1892 - 1894). The wife of U.S. chemist Robert Ogden Doremus, Estelle was a leading member of the American community in Paris during the height of the Second French Empire. Robert Ogden Doremus (January 11, 1824 – March 22, 1906) was an American chemist and physician. Doremus studied at Columbia University and graduated from New York University in 1842 where he came under the influence of John W. Draper; in 1843 he became Draper’s assistant for seven years and aided him in many of his famous researches on light and heat. In 1847 Doremus went to Europe, continuing his chemical studies in Paris with special reference to electrometallurgy, also visiting the establishments where chemical products were manufactured. Doremus married Estelle Emma Skidmore Doremus in 1850. William Nelson's Genealogy of the Doremus Family is available through New York University Libraries via BobCat.Doty, Lockwood Lyon: Albany, NYcuid19001860 July 16 5875

Amos Eaton (May 17, 1776 – 10 May 10, 1842) was an American botanist, geologist, and educator. Eaton is considered the founder of the modern scientific prospectus in education, which was a radical departure from the American liberal arts tradition of classics, religion, lecture, and recitation. In 1824, Eaton co-founded the Rensselaer School with Stephen van Rensselaer III. Eaton’s botany teaching laboratory in the 1820s was the first of its kind in the country; his popular lectures and writings inspired numerous thinkers, in particular women, whom he encouraged to attend his public talks on experimental philosophy. The Amos Eaton Papers (1797-1846) are preserved at the New York State Library Manuscripts and Special Collections in Albany, NY. Eaton, LA: Malden, MAcuid1915[no year] October 11, circa 1880s5910

Charles William Eliot (March 20, 1834 – August 22, 1926) was an American academic and Harvard's president in 1869. Eliot served until 1909, having the longest term as president in the university's history. Eliot was also a cousin of the Nobel Prize-winning poet T.S. Eliot. The Charles William Eliot Papers (1834-1926) are preserved at the Harvard University Archives in Cambridge, MA. Elliott, Henry N: Danversport, MA

Alfred Langdon Elwyn (July 9, 1804 – March 15, 1884) was an author, non-practicing physician, philanthropist, and pioneer in the training and care of mentally disabled in the U.S. Elwyn was one of the founding officers and president of the Pennsylvania Institution for the Blind in 1833. Elwyn also led a Pennsylvania agricultural society and farm school, and was treasurer of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (1849-1870). The town of Elwyn, PA and the care and training facility Elwyn are named for Alfred Elwyn. The Elwyn Historical Archives, The Archives and Library on Disability are preserved at the University of Colorado in Boulder, CO. Ely, Sara M: Brooklyn, NYcuid19231887 April 30 5918

Captain John Ericsson (July 31, 1803 – March 8, 1889) was a Swedish-American inventor and mechanical engineer. Ericsson was born at Långbanshyttan in Värmland, Sweden, but primarily came to be active in England and the United States. Ericsson is remembered best for designing the steam locomotive Novelty (in partnership with engineer John Braithwaite) and the ironclad ship U.S.S. Monitor. William Conant Church’s The Life of John Ericsson is available at New York University Libraries via BobCat. Ernst, CW: Boston, MA cuid19271887 September 7; 1890 January 20 & 235922

James Pollard Espy (the Storm King) (May 9, 1785 – January 24, 1860) was an American meteorologist. Espy developed a convection theory of storms, explaining it in 1836 before the American Philosophical Society and in 1840 before the French Académie des Sciences and the British Royal Society. Espy’s theory was published by in 1840 as The Philosophy of Storms; he became meteorologist to the War (1842) and Navy (1848) departments and developed the use of the telegraph in assembling weather observation data by which he studied the progress of storms and laid the basis for scientific weather forecasting. Espy’s works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.[Ettling, Dr: Giessen, Germany] cuid19291846 March 245924

Edward Everett (April 11, 1794 – January 15, 1865) was an American educator, diplomat, orator, pastor, and politician. Everett, a Whig, served as U.S. Representative, U.S. Senator, the 15th Governor of Massachusetts, Minister to Great Britain, and United States Secretary of State. Everett also taught at Harvard University and served as its president. Everett was one of the great American orators of the antebellum and Civil War eras. The Edward Everett Papers (1807-1864) are preserved at the Harvard University Archives in Cambridge, MA. Faber, W: New York, NYcuid19321843 November 185927

William Francis Ganong (February 19, 1864 - September 7, 1941) was a Canadian botanist, cartographer, and historian. Albert Samuel Gatschet (October 3, 1832 – March 16, 1907) was a Swiss-American ethnologist. Gatschet studied linguistics at the universities of Bern and Berlin, and later moved to the U.S. to study Native American languages. Gatschet became an ethnologist of the U.S. Geological Survey in 1877, and a member of the Smithsonian Institution Bureau of American Ethnology in 1879. Gatschet’s works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat. Gaylord, CN: Goshen, CTcuid19871889 October 2601

Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr. (August 29, 1809 – October 7, 1894) was an American author, lecturer, medical reformer, physician, poet, and professor. Based in Boston, MA, Holmes was a member of the Fireside Poets. The Book & Print Collection of the Holmes Family, also known as the Oliver Wendell Holmes Library, is preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C. In addition, Holmes correspondence is available online through Lehigh University's “I Remain: A Digital Archive of Letters, Manuscripts, and Ephemera.”Hooker, Henrietta E: South Hadley, MAcuid2089[no year] May 4, circa 1880s 6140

Sir John Bennet Lawes (December 28, 1814 – August 31, 1900), 1st Baronet F.R.S. [Fellow of the Royal Society of London for Improving Natural Knowledge], was an English agricultural scientist and entrepreneur. Lawes founded an experimental farm at his home at Rothamsted Manor that eventually became the Rothamsted Experimental Station, where he developed a superphosphate that would mark the beginnings of the chemical fertilizer industry. Lawes archival material is preserved at the Rothamsted Research Library in Harpenden, England, the oldest agricultural research station in the world. Lawson, DS: Weston, MAcuid22211889 July 20 6428

Henry Wadsworth Longfellow (February 27, 1807 – March 24, 1882) was an American educator and poet whose works include "Paul Revere's Ride," The Song of Hiawatha and Evangeline. Longfellow was also one of the five Fireside Poets, and the first American to translate Dante Alighieri's The Divine Comedy. Longfellow archival material is preserved at many repositories including but not limited to the Bowdoin Library in Brunswick, ME, the Harvard College Library in Cambridge, MA, the Longfellow National Historic Site in Cambridge, MA, and the New York Public Library in New York, NY. August Wilhelm von Hofmann (April 8, 1818 – May 5, 1892) was a German chemist. After studying under Justus von Liebig at the University of Giessen, Hofmann became the first director of the Royal College of Chemistry in London in 1845. In 1865, Hofmann returned to Germany to accept a position at the University of Berlin as a teacher and researcher; he also co-founded the German Chemical Society (Deutsche Chemische Gesellschaft) in 1867. In both London and Berlin, Hofmann recreated the style of laboratory instruction established by Liebig at Giessen, fostering a school of chemistry focused on experimental organic chemistry and its industrial applications. Hofmann archival material is preserved at the Imperial College Archives in London, England. von Liebig, Baron Justus Freiherr: Munich, Germanycuid25961868 July 20 - 1888 December 26; undated, circa 1870s - 1880s6973

Measurements: 8" x 5.5" - 11" x 8.5"Subsubseries b: Wellesley College
Historical Note
Wellesley College is a private women's liberal-arts college in the town of Wellesley, west of Boston, MA, and member of the original Seven Sisters Colleges. Henry Fowle Durant and his wife Pauline Adeline Fowle Durant founded Wellesley in 1870. Massachusetts Governor William Claflin signed Wellesley’s charter on March 17, 1870 as Wellesley Female Seminary; the Massachusetts legislature approved the institution’s name change to Wellesley College on March 7, 1873, although it did not open its doors to students until September 8, 1875.
Like the Durants, Eben Norton Horsford was an advocate and supporter of educational opportunities for women. Horsford became the president of the Wellesley College board of visitors, and frequently donated funding for institutional maintenance and supplies. Wellesley dedicated Norumbega Hall in Horsford’s honor in 1886, and was celebrated by the John Greenleaf Whittier poem of the same name.
Notable Wellesley graduates include astronomer Annie Jump Cannon (Class of 1884), author Harriet Stratemeyer Adams (Pseudonym Carolyn Keene, Class of 1914), the former first lady of China, Soong May-ling (Madame Chiang Kai-shek, Class of 1917), U.S. Secretaries of State Madeleine Korbel Albright (Class of 1959) and Hillary Rodham Clinton (Class of 1969), screenwriter Nora Ephron (Class of 1962), journalist Diane Sawyer (Class of 1967), author Alexandra Curry (Class of 1979), and astronaut Pamela Melroy (Class of 1983).
This historical note was written with the help of the finding aids of the Wellesley College Archives.
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series A, Subseries 1, subsubseries b, pertains to Eben Norton Horsford’s professional life in the form of communication with Wellesley administrators, faculty, staff, and students, in addition to American academics and professionals from across the nation. Subsubseries b features documentation in the form of calling / visiting cards, drafts of unsent correspondence, handwritten flyers, invitations, letters and reproductions of letters in the form of photocopies and transcriptions, postcards, printed ephemera in the form of advertisements, clippings, notices, and statements for circulation among the general public, and telegrams.
Subsubseries b features over 109 letters (179 pages) from Wellesley founders Henry Fowle Durant and Pauline Adeline Fowle Durant. Records preserved in this subsubseries trace Horsford’s work as the Wellesley board of visitors president in which he conversed with American activists, architects, astronomers, bibliographers, botanists, economists, editors, educators, historians, indexers, librarians, ministers, philosophers, physicists, social reformers, social scientists, theologians, and writers. In addition, this unique set of correspondence demonstrates Horsford’s friendships and professional relationships with first wave feminists, pioneers of higher education for women, and women’s suffrage supporters including, but not limited to, Ada Howard, Alice Elvira Freeman Palmer, Alice Upton Pearmain, Helen Barrett Montgomery, Katharine Lee Bates (author of the words to “America the Beautiful”), Katharine Coman, Leila S. McKee, Sarah Frances Whiting, Sophonisba Preston Breckinridge, and Susan Hallowell.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].
In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.Letters (correspondence)Commercial correspondence.Newspapers.Notes.Fliers (printed matter)Photocopies.Invitations.Clippings (information artifacts)Postcards.Telegrams.Transcripts.Visiting cards.Personal correspondence.Drafts (documents)Cambridge (Mass.)Boston, MassachusettsBoston (Mass.) |x Intellectual life |y 20th century.Abbess, Laura: New York, NYcuid26711887 November 11715

Helen Barrett Montgomery (July 31, 1861 – October 19, 1934) was an American educator, social reformer, and writer. In 1921, Montgomery was elected as the first woman president of the Northern Baptist Convention (and of any religious denomination in the U.S.). Montgomery had long been a delegate to the Convention and a policymaker. In 1893, she helped found a chapter of the Women’s Educational and Industrial Union in Rochester, NY, and served as president for nearly two decades. In 1899, Montgomery was the first woman elected to the Rochester School Board and any public office in the city, twenty years before women could vote. Montgomery’s published works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat. Katharine Lee Bates (August 12, 1859 – March 28, 1929) was an American author, poet and songwriter. Bates is remembered as the author of the words to the anthem "America the Beautiful." Bates was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1970 and listed as one of the thirty-one LGBT history icons by the organizers of LGBT History Month in 2012. Bates archival material can be found at the Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library on the History of Women in America, Radcliffe College in Cambridge, MA, Falmouth Historical Society in Falmouth, MA, Houghton Library, Harvard University in Cambridge, MA, and Wellesley College Archives in Wellesley, MA."Board of Visitors of Wellesley College" : Wellesley, MAcuid26841886 February 157118

Sophonisba Preston Breckinridge (April 1, 1866 – July 30, 1948) was an American activist, Progressive Era social reformer, and social scientist. Breckinridge was active in several causes including but not limited to: African American Civil Rights, Children’s Protection and Labor Laws Reform, Immigration, Pacifism, Progressive Party, and Women’s Suffrage. The Sophonisba Preston Breckinridge Papers (1905-1949) are preserved at the University of Chicago in Chicago, IL, while the Breckinridge Family Papers (1752-1965) are preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.Brewer, Harriot: Buffalo, NY; Chattanooga, TNcuid26901886 November 12; 1887 June 257124

William Isaac Fletcher (April 23, 1844 - June 15, 1917) was an American bibliographer, indexer, and librarian who served as the head librarian of Amherst College from 1883 to 1911. Alice Elvira Freeman Palmer (February 21, 1855 – December 6, 1902) was an American educator. Freeman was Wellesley College President from 1882 to 1887. Freeman wed Harvard professor George Herbert Palmer in 1887. From 1892 to 1895, she was Dean of Women at the newly founded University of Chicago. Alice Freeman Palmer manuscript material is preserved at Wellesley College in Wellesley, MA.Freeman Palmer, Alice Elvira: East Saginaw, MI; Osborne Hollow, NY; Wellesley, MA cuid27211885 March 10 - 1886 November 17; 1887 July 12; undated, circa 1880s721

Benjamin Apthorp Gould (September 27, 1824 – November 26, 1896) was a pioneering American astronomer. Gould is noted for creating the Astronomical Journal, discovering the Gould Belt, and for founding of the Argentine National Observatory and the Argentine National Weather Service. Gould archival materials can be found at the New York Public Library in New York, NY, and the University of Puget Sound Archives and Special Collections in Tacoma, WA.Gould, Ezra Palmer: Newton, MAcuid27311878 June 22 & October 11; 1881 November 307211

Ezra Palmer Gould (February 27, 1841 – August 22, 1900) was a Baptist and Episcopal minister. Gould graduated Harvard University in 1861 and subsequently served in the American Civil War. Gould entered the ministry in 1868; his commentary on the Gospel of Mark continued to be reprinted in the International Critical Commentary series. Gould’s published work is available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat. Gray, George and Joseph T. Duryea: [Wellesley, MA]cuid27321886 March 107212

James Carruthers Greenough (August 15, 1829 – December 4, 1924) was an American educator. Greenough served as the third principal of the Rhode Island Normal School, sixth president of the Massachusetts Agricultural College, and seventh principal of the Westfield State Normal School. The James Carruthers Greenough Papers (1854-1887) are preserved at the Special Collections & University Archives at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Ada L. Howard (1829 - 1907) was the first president of Wellesley College, and served between 1875 and 1881. Howard graduated from Mount Holyoke College (then Mount Holyoke Female Seminary) in 1853. Before joining Wellesley, Howard taught at Western College in Ohio and was principal of the Woman's Department of Knox College. The Ada Howard Papers at Wellesley College Archives in Wellesley, MA.Howard, H: Methuen, MAcuid27501885 May 19 - June 22; 1886 March 47230

Leila S. McKee (1858 - 1938) was an American education administrator. As second principal and then president of the Western Female Seminary, McKee elevated the institution to a college for women. Alice Whittemore Upton Pearmain (born July 5, 1863) was an American educator, social worker, and suffragist. Pearmain was the president of Wellesley College Alumnae Association and of the organizations connected with the college. Pearmain family archival material is available online via the Smithsonian Archives of American Art. Measurements: 5” x 8”Subsubseries c: Rumford Chemical Works
Historical Note
Eben Norton Horsford and George Francis Wilson formed Rumford Chemical Works in Seekonk, MA (later East Providence, RI) in 1858. Horsford took the namesake from his Rumford Professorship and Lectureship position at Harvard University, which was named after Benjamin Thompson, Count Rumford (1753-1814), a British physicist, inventor, and social reformer. Rumford Chemical Works included a merger with George Francis Wilson & Company (originally called Wilson, Duggan, & Company), which was founded in 1854. Company production included the manufacture of all-purpose baking powder, other phosphates and special chemicals, patent medicines, and fertilizer. Horsford's development of baking powder was designated a National Historic Chemical Landmark in 2006.
Rumford Chemical Works was sold to Heyden Corporation in 1948 while the rights to baking powder were sold to a private owners under the name “Rumford Company.” Essex Chemical Corporation purchased Rumford Chemical Works in 1956; while retaining headquarters in Rumford (East Providence), the company maintains offices around the world. The East Providence headquarters grounds were listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1980.
This historical note was written with the help of the finding aids of “Records pertaining to the Apparatus of the Rumford Professorship and Lectureship on the Application of Science to the Useful Arts” (1835-1836, 1851) at Harvard University, in addition to the Horsford Family Papers (1681-1954) at the Rensselaer Institution Archives and Special Collections.
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series A, Subseries 1, subsubseries c, pertains to Eben Norton Horsford’s professional life in the form of Rumford Chemical Works interdepartmental communication. Subsubseries c features 137 business documents (183 pages) in the form of correspondence, financial records, and light legal notation. This subseries includes genres such as checks, invitations, letters and reproductions of letters, notifications, legal and patent notation, receipts, and telegrams. In addition, this subsubseries features seventy-three letters (eighty-nine pages) from Rumford general manager, secretary, and treasurer, Newton Darling (N.D.) Arnold; as well as twenty-seven letters (thirty-four pages) from Rumford co-founder George F. Wilson.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].
In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.Legal correspondence.Receipts.Financial recordsPhotocopies.Invitations.Telegrams.Notes.Personal papers.Personal correspondence.Commercial correspondence.Letters (correspondence)Providence (R.I.)Anthony, Alfred: Providence, RIcuid28351874 September 177350
