Measurements: 5” x 8” - 8” x 12.5”Wilson, Ray: Providence & Rumford, RIcuid28521889 August 12 & 27, November 87367Subsubseries d: American Civil War Army Rations
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series A, Subseries 1, subsubseries d, pertains to Eben Norton Horsford’s professional life in the form of communication with entrepreneurs, medical inspectors, physicians, and a variety of high-ranking officials from the U.S. Army and Navy during the American Civil War. Subsubseries d features seventy-six letters (183 pages) that document Horsford’s unsuccessful trial manufacture of a chemically-enhanced ration of grain and meat designed to provide nutrition to troops. These contents trace the progression of Horsford’s recipe with word from Albion Parris Howe, Amos Beebe Eaton, Colonel John Cunningham Kelton, Dr. Ferdinand Vandeveer Hayden, General George Gordon Meade, General Marsena Rudolph Patrick, General Ulysses S. Grant, Lewis Henry Morgan, Lieutenant Colonel William B. Guernsey, Quartermaster General Montgomery Cunningham Meigs, Rear Admiral Charles Henry Davis, and Secretary of War, Edwin McMasters Stanton. In addition, this subsubseries includes a uniquely negative critique of Horsford’s chemical creation from Union soldier “L.R. Williams,” who served in the 5th Regiment, Kansas Volunteer Calvary.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].
In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.Notes.Letters (correspondence)Commercial correspondence.Clippings (information artifacts)Transcripts.Photocopies.Printed ephemera.Grant, Ulysses S. Charles Henry Davis (January 16, 1807 – February 18, 1877) was a Rear Admiral in the U.S. Navy. Working for the Coast Survey, Davis researched tides and currents, and located an uncharted shoal that had caused wrecks off the New York coast. During the American Civil War, he commanded the Western Gunboat Flotilla, winning an important engagement in the Battle of Memphis, before capturing enemy supplies on a successful expedition up the Yazoo river. Davis’ published works can be found at New York University Libraries via Bobcat. Eaton, Amos Beebe: New York, NY; Washington, D.C.cuid28551865 February 18 & 20, March 15743

Ulysses S. Grant (born Hiram Ulysses Grant; April 27, 1822 – July 23, 1885) was the 18th President of the United States (1869–1877). As Commanding General, Grant worked closely with President Abraham Lincoln to lead the Union Army to victory over the Confederacy in the American Civil War. Grant implemented Congressional Reconstruction, often at odds with Lincoln's successor, Andrew Johnson. Twice elected president, Grant led the Republicans in their effort to remove the vestiges of Confederate nationalism and slavery, protect African-American citizenship, and support economic prosperity nationwide. The Ulysses S. Grant Papers (1844-1922) are preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C. Guernsey, Lieutenant Colonel William B: Beaufort, SCcuid28571865 January 13745

Dr. Ferdinand Vandeveer Hayden (September 7, 1829 – December 22, 1887) was an American geologist noted for his pioneering surveying expeditions of the Rocky Mountains in the late 19th century. Hayden was also a physician who served with the Union Army during the American Civil War. Mike Foster’s Strange Genius: The Life of Ferdinand Vandeveer Hayden (1994), in addition to Hayden’s published works are available in New York University Libraries via Bobcat. Colonel John Cunningham Kelton (June 24, 1828 – July 15, 1893) was a U.S. Army officer; he served as the Adjutant General of the U.S. Army from 1889 to 1892. Kelton was appointed to the 6th Infantry, in which he served until the outbreak of the American Civil War; he served in various staff positions during the war including the rank Colonel of Volunteers. Kelton correspondence can be found in the Cutts-Madison Papers (1759-1912) at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, MA.Macy, CR: New York, NYcuid28701864 September 10; October 29; November 237418

George Gordon Meade (December 31, 1815 – November 6, 1872) was a career U.S. Army officer and civil engineer involved in the coastal construction of several lighthouses. Meade fought with distinction in the Second Seminole War and the Mexican-American War. During the American Civil War, Meade served as a Union general, rising from command of a brigade to the Army of the Potomac. Meade is best known for defeating Confederate General Robert E. Lee at the Battle of Gettysburg in 1863. The George Gordon Meade Collection (1811-1897) is preserved at the Historical Society of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, PA. Lewis Henry Morgan (November 21, 1818 – December 17, 1881) was a pioneering American anthropologist, lawyer, and social theorist. Morgan is best known for his work on kinship and social structure, his theories of social evolution, and his ethnography of the Iroquois. Morgan entered the U.S. Army by the intervention of his friend, Ulysses S. Grant, and served on Grant's staff during the American Civil War. The Lewis Henry Morgan Papers (1826-1996) are preserved at the River Campus Library, University of Rochester in Rochester, NY. Patrick, Marsena Rudolph: Geneva, NYcuid28761865 September 8 7424

Biographical Note
Mary L’Hommedieu Gardiner Horsford was born on September 26, 1824 to Samuel Smith Gardiner and Mary Catherine Gardiner. Mary was privately tutored on Shelter Island before attending the Albany Female Academy, where she met Eben Norton Horsford. Mary and Eben wed in 1847 and later produced four daughters: “Lilian” (Mary Leila Horsford Farlow), “Kate” (Mary Katherine Horsford), Gertrude Hubbard Horsford Fiske, and “Mamie” (Mary Gardiner Horsford Curtis). Mary was a poet and had several works published in local newspapers; her volume Indian Legends and Other Works was published in 1855. Mary passed away on November 25, 1855, only months after Mamie was born.
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series B, pertains to Mary L’Hommedieu Horsford’s personal and public life in the form of two series arranged by genre. Series 1: Correspondence includes communication in the form of invitations and letters. Series 2: Manuscripts and Printed Materials consists of private and professional documentation in the form of diary entries, collected and original poetry by Mary and others, records of Mary’s writing process in the form of manuscripts, printing proofs, and typescripts of her work Indian Legends and Other Poems. Series 2 also includes ephemera and printed materials in the form of a personal bible full of marginalia; Jared Bell Waterbury’s Advice to a Young Christian on the Importance of Aiming at an Elevated Standard of Piety (1830) was once a part of this series, but it has been removed to the Fales Special Collections and cataloged. Please search Bobcat to locate this work.Subseries 1: Correspondence
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series B, Subseries 1, pertains to Mary L’Hommedieu Gardiner Horsford’s personal and public life in the form of communication with her family, friends, and members of her local community. Genres range from contact in the form of invitations, letters, and collected and original poetry.
Series D, Subseries 1, is dominated by records that capture Mary’s personal life through conversations with her family and friends. Subjects range from current community events, private family business and Shelter Island estate management, to public and shared social experiences, testimonies of religious faith, to travel. This subseries features seventy-seven letters (281 pages) from “A.D.W.” or “Cousin Abby,” (possibly Abby Dwight Woodbridge), in which Abby shares her love of poetry with Mary.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].
In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.Personal correspondence.Personal papers.Poetry.Printed ephemera.Invitations.Notes.Letters (correspondence)Botta, Anne C. The Bobcat call number is as follows: BV4520 .W3 1830b Box Non-circulating.Series C: Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford
Biographical Note
Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford was born on August 13, 1826 to Samuel Smith Gardiner and Mary Catherine L’Hommedieu Gardiner. With sister Mary Gardiner Horsford, Phoebe was privately tutored until she attended Albany Female Academy and met Eben Norton Horsford. Phoebe was an accomplished seamstress and married Eben Norton Horsford on July 22, 1857, after his first wife, her sister Mary, passed away just two years earlier. Eben and Phoebe produced one daughter, “Nellie” (Cornelia Conway Felton Horsford). Phoebe passed away October 8, 1900 in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series C, pertains to Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford’s personal and public life in the form of three series arranged by record type. Subseries 1: Correspondence includes communication in the form of invitations, letters, and telegrams. Subseries 2: Financial and Legal consists of account books, appraisals, home and life insurance documentation, inventories, tax records, and three drafts of Phoebe’s will. Subseries 3: Notebooks and Printed Materials features private papers in the form ephemera, manuscripts, and notation, with collected and original poetry and genealogical writing.
Subseries 1 is arranged alphabetically by company or individual surname, while the materials of Subseries 2 and Subseries 3 are arranged alphabetically by record type[s] and provided title. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.Subseries 1: Correspondence
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series C, Subseries 1, pertains to Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford’s personal and public life in the form of communication with her family, friends, and an assortment of aristocracy. Genres range from contact in the form of announcements, calling / visiting cards, financial records in the form of bills, checks, and receipts, invitations, illustrations, letters, notation, manuscripts of travel writing, ornate lace valentines featuring bird, floral, and hair designs, original and collected poetry, photographs, postcards, and telegrams; and original and reproductions of printed ephemera in the form of advertisements, newsprint clippings, and pamphlets.
Series D, Subseries 1, is dominated by records that capture Phoebe’s personal life, featuring over 361 letters (2,065 pages) just from her immediate family. Subjects range from current community events, local and international travel, to private family business and Shelter Island estate management, public and shared social experiences, to testimonies of religious faith. This subseries features communication with the New England elite of the period including Anne Charlotte Lynch Botta, Caroline Lane Jebb, Edith Longfellow Dana and Richard Henry Dana III, Elizabeth Aspinwall Pulsifer Wyman and Morrill Wyman, Frederick Albion Ober, Helen Hunt Jackson, Henry James, Sr., Henry Van Brunt, James Russell Lowell, Julia Gardiner Tyler, Sara Chapman Thorp Bull, and Sarah Orne Jewett. In addition, these contents include genealogical information from Fannie Washington Finch (Frances Louisa Augustus Washington Finch), great-great niece of the first president of the United States, George Washington.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].
In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. Richard Henry Dana III (January 3, 1851 - December 16, 1931) was an American lawyer, civil service reformer, and Harvard graduate. Dana was the son of Richard Henry Dana Jr., and Harvard graduate; he married in 1878 to Edith Longfellow (1853 – 1915), the daughter of poet Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. Family archival materials can be found at Harvard (the Houghton Library and the Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library at Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study), the Massachusetts Historical Society, the Middlebury College Library (Abernathy Collections), and the Longfellow House at Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site.Davis Collamore & Company, Limited: New York, NYcuid35461887 July 11 & 199224

Henry James, Sr. (June 3, 1811 in Albany, New York – December 18, 1882 in Boston, Massachusetts) was an American theologian and adherent of Swedenborgianism. The Mary Fiske Stoughton House is a National Historic Landmark house at 90 Brattle Street in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Henry Hobson Richardson designed the house in 1882 in what is now called the “Shingle Style,” with a minimum of ornament and shingles stretching over the building's irregular volumes like a skin. The house drew immediate notice in the architectural community, and was a significant influence in the growth in popularity of the Shingle style in the late 19th century. Richardson's masterful use of space in its design also foreshadowed the work of major 20th century architects, including Frank Lloyd Wright. The house was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1989.Taussig, Frank William: St. Louis, MO cuid36581884 July 109516

Biographical Note
"Lilian," (Mary Leila Horsford Farlow, September 18, 1848 - August 16, 1927) was the eldest daughter of Mary L'Hommedieu Gardiner Horsford and Eben Norton Horsford. Lilian travelled often with her father, accompanying him to Europe in 1873 and 1880, and on a trip to the western United States in 1880 - 1881. Lilian was affiliated with both Radcliffe and Wellesley Colleges, and active in campaigning for educational opportunities for women. Lilian resided in the Horsford family home in Cambridge, MA, until her marriage to Dr. William Gilson Farlow on December 10, 1900.
William Gilson Farlow (December 17, 1844 - June 3, 1919) was an American botanist. Born in Boston, MA, and educated at Harvard (A.B. 1866; M.D. 1870), and after several years of European study, Farlow became an adjunct professor of botany in 1874 and professor of cryptogamic botany in 1879. Farlow corresponded with Caroline Bingham and Jacob Georg Agardh to collaborate in the identification and classification of species of algae previously unknown to science. In 1899, Farlow became the president of the American Society of Naturalists; in 1904, president of the National Academy of Sciences; in 1905, president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science; and in 1911, president of the Botanical Society of America. Farlow received honorary degrees from Harvard University, the University of Glasgow (LL.D 1901), and the University of Wisconsin–Madison.
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series D, pertains to Mary Leila Horsford Farlow’s personal and public life in the form of two series arranged by record type. Series 1: Correspondence includes communication in the form of letters, greeting cards, photographs, postcards, and printed ephemera. Series 2: Notebooks and Printed Materials consists of private and professional documentation in the form of a booklet, collected and original artwork and poetry, financial records in the form of account books, notation, and receipts, juvenilia, and manuscripts and notebooks of collected research.Subseries 1: Correspondence
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series D, Subseries 1, pertains to Lilian’s personal and public life in the form of communication with her family, friends, and local professionals. Record types range from contact in the form of announcements, greeting cards, invitations, illustrations, letters, notation, original and collected poetry, photographs, postcards, and receipts; and printed ephemera in the form of advertisements, clippings, and pamphlets.
Series D, Subseries 1, is dominated by records that capture Lilian’s personal life through conversations with her family and friends. Subjects range from current community events, genealogical and history inquiries, private family business and Shelter Island estate management, public and shared social experiences, to local and international travel. This subseries features twenty-six letters (129 pages) from Lilian’s sister Kate, Mary Katherine Horsford, while Lilian visited both Gardiners Island and Shelter Island, and while Kate traveled throughout the American midwest and northeast.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].
In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. Elizabeth Cabot Agassiz (née Cary) (December 5, 1822 – June 27, 1907) was an American educator, and the co-founder and first president of Radcliffe College. As a researcher of natural history, she was a contributing author to many scientific published works with her husband, Louis Agassiz. The Elizabeth Cabot Cary Agassiz Papers (1822-1907) are preserved at the Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe College Archives, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University, in Cambridge, MA. David Gardiner Tyler (July 12, 1846 – September 5, 1927), was a lawyer, judge, and United States Democratic Party politician. David was the first child of John Tyler, the tenth President of the United States and his second wife Julia Gardiner Tyler; he dropped out of present-day Washington and Lee University to fight in the Confederate Army during the American Civil War. The Tyler Family Papers (1716-1946) are preserved at the Earl Gregg Swem Library at The College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, VA. Tyler, Julia Gardiner: Richmond, VAcuid37641886 June 39844

Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series D, Subseries 2, consists of Lilian's private papers including artwork in the form of pencil illustrations and a watercolor painting, financial records in the form of an account book, notes and receipts, juvenila in the form of paper dolls and pressed plants, and personal writing. Lilian's journal, manuscripts, and notebooks are full of genealogical and historical research, inventories, recipes, and poetry. Although Series D, Subseries 2 is dominated by personal documentation, these contents also include an account book detailing estate management for the Harlow and Gardiner property on Shelter Island between 1893 - 1918, tax receipts for the Union Free School District No. 1 on Shelter Island from 1915, and a handwritten reissue of a Rumford Chemical Works Patent from 1921.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by record type[s] and provided title. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. [Booklet with Envelope, Inscription & Notation] cuid37811903; 1921 June 189912Series E: Mary Katherine Horsford (Kate)
Biographical Note
Mary Katherine Horsford (1850 - 1927), “Kate” was the second daughter of Mary L’Hommedieu Gardiner Horsford and Eben Norton Horsford. Born in Cambridge, MA, Kate was fond of writing poetry, sketching, and watercolor painting; she also accompanied her father to Europe during his trip to the Vienna Exposition in 1873. Kate never wed and lived at Sylvester Manor with her sister Cornelia Conway Felton Horsford, where she contributed to the ground’s garden development.
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series E, pertains to Mary Katherine Horsford's personal and public life in the form of two series arranged by record type. Series 1: Correspondence includes communication in the form of accessories (bracelets), letters, greeting cards, photographs, postcards, printed ephemera, telegrams, and visiting cards. Series 2: Notebooks and Printed Materials consists of private papers in the form of a financial record, a sketchbook, a selection of travel writing, bound research and visitor lists, and original poetry.Subseries 1: Correspondence
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series E, Subseries 1, pertains Kate’s personal and public life in the form of communication with her family, friends, and local and international professionals. Genres range from contact in the form of accessories (bracelets), greeting cards, engravings, invitations, letters, notation, original and collected poetry, photographs, postcards, telegrams, and visiting cards; and ephemera in the form of advertisements, flyers, and pamphlets.
Series E, Subseries 1, is dominated by records that capture Kate’s personal life through conversations with her family and friends. Subjects range from current community events, genealogical and history inquiries, private family business, public and shared social experiences, to local and international travel. This subseries features eleven letters from American chemist Charles Avery Doremus (September 6, 1851 - December 2, 1925) while he was completing his PhD at the universities of Leipzig and Heidelberg in Germany between 1870 - 1873. The son of chemist and physician Robert Ogden Doremus, Charlie became a toxicology expert and a holder of patents for a process of softening water, a gas furnace, producing hydrofluoric acid, extracting alumina from clay, and extracting potash from feldspar.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].

Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series E, Subseries 2 consists of Mary Katherine Horsford, "Kate's" private papers in the form of a financial record, a sketchbook, a selection of travel writing, research, visitor lists, and original poetry.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by record type and provided title. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.Financial Record: "Ab'm Besthoff & Son" Receiptcuid38321886 April 1010029Notebook: "Painters," [With Visitor List]cuid38331872 July 10030[Poetry by Mary Katherine Horsford]cuid38341915; 1926 September 25; undated, circa 1915 - 192610031Printed Materials: Addresses in Commemoration of Josiah Parsons Cooke, Late President of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, [Booklet with Inscription]cuid38351894 December 1210032Printed Materials: "Ex Libris Katharine Horsford," [Book Plate Engraving Prints]cuid3836undated, circa 190010033Sketchbook: [Landscapes & Portraits in Pencil] cuid3837187910034Travel Writing: "Journal at Newport to Gerty Wells" cuid38381887 September10035Series F: Gertrude Hubbard Horsford Fiske
Biographical Note
Gertrude Hubbard Horsford Fiske (1852 - 1920) was born to Eben Norton Horsford and Mary L’Hommedieu Gardiner Horsford in Cambridge, MA. Gertrude married Boston attorney Andrew Fiske (1854 - 1897) in 1878, and they produced five children: Impressionist figure and landscape painter Gertrude Horsford Fiske (1879 - 1961), Dr. Augustus Henry Fiske (born 1880), Eben Norton Fiske (born 1883), Gardiner Horsford Fiske (born 1892), and Cornelia Horsford Fiske (Mrs. Harold Willis) (born 1895).
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series F pertains to Gertrude Hubbard Horsford Fiske’s personal life in the form of letters from her friends and sisters.
These materials are arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].
In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.Cheever, Elizabeth: Far Rockaway, NYcuid38391871 June 30 1011

Biographical Note
Mary Gardiner Horsford Curtis (August 27, 1855 - 1893) “Mamie” was the youngest daughter of Mary L’Hommedieu Gardiner and Eben Norton Horsford. Mamie married the son of a U.S. Supreme Court Justice & Rhode Island attorney and judge, Benjamin Robbins Curtis (June 8, 1855 - January 21, 1891) in 1877. Mamie and Benjamin produced one daughter: Mary Gardiner Curtis (July 5, 1879 - May 11, 1961).
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series G pertains to Mamie's personal life in the form of letters from her friends and sisters.

Measurements: 4” x 6.25”Series H: Cornelia Conway Felton Horsford (Nellie)
Biographical Note
“Nellie” (Cornelia Conway Felton Horsford, September 25, 1861 - 1944) was the only daughter of Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford and Eben Norton Horsford. Cornelia was an amateur watercolor painter, a poet, and travelled extensively; family trips around the North American west and Europe influenced her interest in archaeology, gardening, and history. While continuing Eben Norton Horsford’s Northmen and Norumbega work, Cornelia sponsored an expedition to Iceland to compare structures built by Viking settlers to those in Massachusetts. Cornelia also conducted Sylvester family genealogical and Shelter Island local history research. After Phoebe Dayton Gardiner Horsford passed away in 1900, Cornelia managed Sylvester Manor and oversaw a substantial renovation in 1908.
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series H pertains to Nellie's personal and professional life in which it includes correspondence, clippings and ephemera, genealogical and local history research, financial and legal records, notebooks, photographs, printed works, original and collected artwork and poetry, and Sylvester Manor blueprints and inventories for the 1908 renovation.
Selected printed materials have been removed to Fales Special collections and cataloged. Please search Bobcat to locate these items.Subseries 1: Correspondence
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series H, Subseries 1, consists of Nellie's personal and professional correspondence, but also includes financial records, legal records, and research. Genres range from communication in the form of greeting cards, invitations, letters, notation, original and collected artwork and poetry, photographs, postcards, telegrams, and visiting cards; ephemera in the form of flyers, pamphlets, pressed plants, a recreational sport booklet, and newsprint clippings; financial records in the form of insurance and stock account notation; and legal records in the form of employee and property contracts, inventories, and wills.
Series H, Subseries 1, is dominated by items that capture Cornelia’s personal life through communication with family and friends. Subjects range from local current events, obituaries, travel, and weddings, to contact with her nephews Lieutenant Gardiner Horsford Fiske and Gouverneur Morris Phelps while they were both serving in the American Expeditionary Forces during World War I. Series H, Subseries 1 preserves Cornelia’s professional life in the form of research; subjects range from gardening, genealogy, to local history and Sylvester Manor estate management, in which Cornelia conducts conversations with academics, businessmen, librarians, legal and real estate professionals, and government workers. This subseries also includes prints of twenty-four United States patents assigned by Dr. Augustus Henry Fiske while he was chief chemist at Rumford Chemical Works. See related records in Record Group V: Fiske Family, Series A: Correspondence and Research, Box 117, Folder 41, for Andrew Fiske’s collection of his father’s patents.

Gardiner Horsford Fiske enlisted as a flying cadet in Boston on April 30, 1917, and had training at Chandler Field, PA, before serving at Issoudon and Clermont-Ferrad, France during World War I. Fiske received his commission as 1st Lieutenant with the 20th Aero Squadron on January 27, 1918. One of Lt. Fiske’s war adventures was when acting as an observer, he was thrown from his cockpit 2000 feet in the air, miraculously landed in front of the vertical stabilizer, and managed to crawl back into the aircraft. Fiske, then a Major, was an Intelligence Officer for the Eighth Air Force during World War II. Fiske’s scrapbook is preserved at the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum in Washington, D.C. Albert Samuel Gatschet (October 3, 1832, Beatenberg, Canton of Bern – March 16, 1907) was a Swiss-American ethnologist who trained as a linguist in the universities of Bern and Berlin, but later moved to the United States in order to study Native American languages, a field in which he was a pioneer. The Albert Samuel Gatschet Papers (1828-1906) are preserved in the National Anthropological Archives at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C.Gouwe and Helena: Honolulu, HI; Shelter Island, NYcuid39161928 March 2 - 3; undated, circa 19281032

William James (January 11, 1842 – August 26, 1910) was an American philosopher and psychologist. Son of Henry James, Sr., and brother to diarist Alice James, and novelist Henry James, William was trained as a physician, and the first educator to offer a psychology course in the United States. Williams was one of the leading thinkers of the late 19th century and is often referred to as the "Father of American psychology." The William James Papers (1842-1910) are preserved at the Houghton Library, Harvard College Library, in Cambridge, MA. Keene, A: London, Englandcuid39411924 April 10; undated, circa 19241043

Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series I: Assorted Horsford Materials contain documentation related to the Horsford family that belonged to multiple individuals or a case in which identification of a specific creator or owner could not be determined. Genres range from ephemera, gardening documentation, genealogical and local history research, newspapers and clippings, personal and professional correpsondence, poetry and personal manuscripts, Sylvester Manor financial papers, and a variety of printed materials such as clippings and newspapers.Subseries 1: Correspondence
Scope and Contents
Record Group IV, Series I, Subseries 1 is arranged alphabetically by the company name or surname of the individual in contact.
Record titles reflect this arrangement by taking the form: [Surname, First Name]: [Location].
In the case that a set of correspondence includes multiple authors or the surname of the individual are unidentified, record titles reflect administrative categories, first names, initials, or nicknames, with possible surnames and locations provided in brackets. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same subseries.Archery Club of Shelter Island cuid4133undated, circa 1860 - 18901099

Measurements: 4" x 7"
Maria Lydig Daly (1824 - 1894) was an American Democrat, Dirarist, and Unionist. Maria is the author of Diary of a Union Lady, 1861-1865, was active in the Democratic Party, the Women's Central Association for the Relief for the Army, the New York Botanical Garden, and many other collectives during the American Civil War. Daly was the daughter of Philip Mesier Lydig (1739 - 1872), the last landholder of the property that became the Bronx Park and the New York Botanical Garden, and Katherine Suydam, eldest daughter of John Suydam, an early settler of New Netherland, also known as a "Knickerbocker." Maria married jurist, lecturer, and writer Charles Patrick Daly (1816 - 1899), who was a member of the New York State Assembly, Chief Justice of the New York Court of Common Pleas, and president of the American Geographical Society. The Charles Patrick Daly Papers (1829-1897) are preserved at the New York Public Library, Archives and Manuscripts Division, in New York, NY. Dyer, Louis: Cambridge, MA cuid41431884 July 1110919

Biographical Note
Andrew Fiske (February 21, 1909 - August 31, 1992) was born in Cambridge, MA to Augustus Henry Fiske and Esther Bennett. Andrew was a thirteenth generation descendant of Nathaniel Sylvester and inherited Shelter Island upon the passing of his father in 1949. Andrew was a Harvard College and Business School graduate, and managed the Groton, CT Electric Boat Company during World War II. Fiske was the Long Island representative for Boston brokerage firm H.C. Wainwright, and was a founder, trustee and president of the Suffolk County Library. Fiske served for more than forty years on the Shelter Island Public Library board, and served for more than twenty years on the Shelter Island school board, the Eastern Long Island Hospital board, and with the Suffolk County Historical Society.
Alice Hench Fiske (November 9, 1917 - April 17, 2006) was born in Youngstown, OH to Laverne Willis Hench and Florence Ebersbach Hench. Alice graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1939 and married Andrew Fiske in 1952. Alice helped restore Sylvester Manor and its gardens to their 19th century glory. As the founder of the Andrew Fiske Memorial Center for Archaeological Research at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, she sponsored digs at Sylvester Manor. Alice was also a supporter of the Shelter Island Library, Shelter Island Historical Society, and the Shelter Island Garden Club.
Scope and Contents
Record Group V: Fiske Family includes Sylvester Manor research conducted by Andrew and his wife Alice. Genres range from original and reproductions of ephemera, legal records, personal and professional correspondence, personal writing, and printed materials.Professional Correspondencecuid45791929 July 211740

Margaret W. Rossiter (born July 1944) is an American educator and Marie Underhill Noll Professor of the History of Science at Cornell University. Rossiter coined the term "Matilda Effect" for the systematic repression and denial of the contribution of women scientists in research, whose work is often attributed to their male colleagues. Rossiter's works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat. Research Clipping [Photocopies]cuid46001973 July 2711816

Scope and Contents
Record Group VI includes the collection's photographic material. These items largely document the Horsford family and the Sylvester Manor grounds. Photographic formats include cabinet cards and carte de visite, a variety of portrait prints of Horsford and Fiske family members, in addition to glass and film negatives, photo albums, scrapbooks, and tintypes.Series A: People and PortraitsPhotographic Print: Portrait of Anne de Peyster van Cortlandtundated, circa 1850 - 190011934

Scope and Contents
Record Group VII: Artifacts includes original housing containers in the form of document boxes, letter files, trunks, and wallets. These containers once provided storage for the documents and photographs previously described in this collection.Metal Lockboxundated156
Provenance
This metal lockbox belonged to Andrew Fiske.Metal Lockbox undated157
Scope and Contents
This metal lockbox includes letter satchels, small frames, a cigar box with ship records, and metal writing implements; the metal writing implements were originally housed with the materials from Box 107, Folder 25.Assorted Containers undated158
Scope and Contents
This assortment includes empty boxes, file folders, and letter wallets that once housed correspondence and photographic negatives.Oversize Boards undated159
Scope and Contents
These containers once housed engravings, large maps, and other oversize documents.
